metafoor_inventaris.metafoor_expressie: God is going to make the figures come out right.

cognitieve_implicaties: There is a cosmic 'debt' or 'error' that must be resolved.
theologische_implicaties: God is the ultimate Accountant/Judge of history.
Justification is not just ignoring sin but fixing the moral math.
ethische_implicaties: Believers can let go of vengeance because the 'books' will be balanced by God.
onbedoelde_consequenties: May suggest a cold, impersonal view of God as a calculator.

metafoor_inventaris.vitaliteit_toelichting: The preacher uses 'lingo of today' to re-activate the dead metaphor of 'justification' by linking it to accounting/rectification.

coherentie_analyse.coherentie_verklaring: The preacher successfully bridges the Juridical domain (Courtroom) with the Economic domain (Cost/Price) through the concept of 'Costly Grace'. The tension between 'free' and 'costly' is resolved by shifting the cost from the recipient to the Giver.

incoherentie_punten.locatie: Discussion of South Africa and Susan Cohen
incoherentie_punten.conflict_beschrijving: The preacher argues forgiveness is a gift, but then validates Susan Cohen's rage that 'no one has been punished,' creating a tension between unconditional gift and necessary punishment.
incoherentie_punten.entailment_conflict: If it is a gift, it requires no payment; if it is rectification, it requires the 'figures' to be balanced by payment/punishment.

succesvolle_blending.blending_strategie: The courtroom is transformed into a scene of family reunion, where the 'verdict' of the judge results in the restoration of the family unit.

sterktes.beschrijving: The preacher identifies that 'justification' is a dead metaphor for modern hearers and revitalizes it using the 'accounting' and 'rectification' language.
sterktes.voorbeeld: God is going to make the figures come out right.

risicos.beschrijving: Heavy use of 'cheap' vs 'costly' grace can inadvertently frame the Gospel in purely market-based terms.
risicos.voorbeeld: God’s grace is free, but it is not cheap, for it cost the Lord a price so great.
risicos.potentiele_impact: Congregation may view their relationship with God as a transaction they are perpetually 'indebted' to.

text_world_analyse.primaire_wereld: A cosmic courtroom where God is both Judge and the one who pays the fine.
sub_worlds: The solitary confinement cell of Father Jenco in Beirut
The Truth and Reconciliation hearings in South Africa
The grieving home of Susan Cohen

deictic_shifts.naar_wereld: The courtroom in South Africa with Bishop Tutu weeping
deictic_shifts.effectiviteit: Highly effective in grounding the abstract concept of 'costly' forgiveness in physical emotion (weeping).

versterkte_schemas.hoe_versterkt: Repeated emphasis on God 'taking care of' wickedness and 'rectifying' all things.

verstoorde_schemas.verstoring_strategie: Contrasting 'cheap grace' with the 'agony of those who suffer injustice'.

schema_analyse.liturgische_schema_aansluiting: Strongly aligns with the 'Christian confession of sin' mentioned in the introduction.

aanbevelingen.metafoor_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is anchored in the Juridical and Economic domains, which is appropriate for a text from Romans. It avoids the 'Medical' domain entirely, focusing instead on the objective status of the believer before a cosmic tribunal. The use of the 'Pilgrimage' metaphor provides a necessary temporal element to the otherwise static legal metaphors.

revitalisatie_suggesties.suggestie: Continue the 'making the figures come out right' imagery but perhaps link it to 'restoration of a broken masterpiece' to add an aesthetic/creative dimension.
revitalisatie_suggesties.voorbeeld: God is the master restorer who doesn't just paint over the scratches but rebuilds the canvas.

coherentie_verbeteringen.incoherentie: The tension between 'no condemnation' and 'standing before the judgment seat'.
coherentie_verbeteringen.resolutie_strategie: Clarify the distinction between 'Judgment for evaluation/truth' and 'Condemnation for punishment' more explicitly using the 'Full Disclosure' model from the South Africa example.

entailment_checks.problematisch_entailment: If grace is 'costly', who paid? If God paid Himself, the 'cost' metaphor can become circular or suggest a split in the Trinity (angry Father vs. paying Son).
entailment_checks.aanbeveling: Emphasize the unity of God's will in the sacrifice to avoid 'divine child abuse' entailments.

alternatieve_domeinen.rationale: To support the idea of 'rectification' (straightening what is crooked).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in using CMT to bridge 1st-century Pauline theology with 20th-century global events. The preacher successfully moves from the 'head' (legal status) to the 'heart' (the weeping Bishop) without losing theological precision.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_esthetiek: An aesthetic analysis would praise the use of the Hamlet quote; CMT reveals that the Hamlet quote functions as a 'readiness' schema for receiving a gift.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_kolb: Kolb would focus on the 'experience' of the hostages; CMT focuses on how the 'Pilgrimage' metaphor structures the hostage's cognitive processing of time and pain.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_CMT: CMT reveals that the preacher is using 'Justification' not as a legal verdict but as a 'Balance' image-schema (making figures right), which is more cognitively accessible than forensic jargon.

appendices.notities: The sermon relies heavily on the 'Costly Grace' schema from Bonhoeffer to bridge the Economic and Juridical domains.
